1:
Man, who is born of woman,\q lives only a few days and is full of trouble.
\q
2:
He sprouts from the ground like a flower and is cut down;\q he flees like a shadow and does not last.
\q
3:
Do you look at any of these?\q Do you bring me into judgment with you?


\q
4: Who can bring something clean out of something unclean? No one.\q
6:
Look away from him that he may rest,\q so that he may enjoy his day like a hired man if he can do so.
\m


\q
7:
There can be hope for a tree;\q if it is cut down, it might sprout again,
\q so that its tender stalk does not disappear.
\q
8:
Though its root grows old in the earth,\q and its stump dies in the ground,
\q
9:
yet even if it only smells water, it will bud\q and send out branches like a plant.


\q
10:
But man dies; he becomes weak;\q indeed, man stops breathing, and then where is he?
\q
11:
As water disappears from a lake,\q and as a river loses water and dries up,
\q
12:
so people lie down and do not rise again.\q Until the heavens are no more, they will not awake
\q nor be roused out of their sleep.
\m


\q
13:
Oh, that you would hide me away in Sheol away from troubles,\q and that you would keep me in private until your wrath is over,
\q that you would set me a fixed time to stay there and then call me to mind!
\q
14:
If a man dies, will he live again?\q If so, I would wish to wait all my weary time there
\q until my release should come.


\q
15:
You would call, and I would answer you.\q You would have a desire for the work of your hands.
\q
16:
You would number and care for my footsteps;\q you would not keep track of my sin.
\q
17:
My transgression would be sealed up in a bag;\q you would cover up my iniquity.
\m


\q
18:
But even mountains fall and come to nothing;\q even rocks are moved out of their place;
\q
19:
the waters wear down the stones;\q their flooding washes away the dust of the earth.
\q Like this, you destroy the hope of man.


\q
20:
You always defeat him, and he passes away;\q you change his face and send him away to die.
\q
21:
If his sons are honored, he does not know it;\q and if they are brought low, he does not see it.
\q
22: He feels only the pain of his own body,\q and he mourns for himself.
